alert.note: Alert for Cook; Koochiching; Lake; St. Louis (Minnesota) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Duluth (Northeast Minnesota and Northern Wisconsin)
info.headline: Hydrologic Outlook issued May 03 at 11:14AM CDT by NWS Duluth
info.description: ...SPRING SNOWMELT IS CAUSING HIGH WATER LEVELS WITHIN THE RAINY LAKE BASIN... A melting and moisture-rich snowpack has caused strong rises on area rivers and lakes. Minor flooding is occurring along rivers across northeast Minnesota, particularly along the tributaries and the main stem of the Rainy River Basin. Rainfall from this past weekend, combined with recent snow melt, have caused rises on area rivers including the Littlefork, Big Fork, Pelican, Rat Root, Vermilion and Rainy Rivers. While not as high as last weeks crests, high water continues on all of these water bodies. Most areas will see receding flows this week ahead as dry weather takes hold. However, strong flows into Crane, Kabetogama and Namakan lakes will cause continued lake level rises. As Rainy Lake continues to rise, the outflow from the dam at International Falls will also increase, causing rising water levels in the Rainy River. Expect high flows within the Rainy Lake system for the next several weeks. The next chance for precipitation and possible thunderstorms are expected late this weekend.
